comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Douglas AD-6/A-1H Skyraider 137587 VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ Modex 312 Tail code NF of Carrier Air Group / Wing Five (CVG-5 / CVW-5) The squadron was part of the air group/wing from 1960 to 1966. Wheels chocked on airfield ramp under cloudy skies Color profile of AD-6 137587from VA-145 when part of CVG-14 code A assigned to CVA-12 USS Hornet 1956-1957: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/a/593/3/16#23 (click on picture alongside following text to view profile) AD-6 (A-1H) Unit: VA-145, US Navy Serial: 513/A (BuNo.137587) CVA-12 USS Hornet, circa 1956. A-1H Skyraider 137587 may have been transferred early on to the air force of South Vietnam (VNAF) There is reference that A-1H 137587 may have been used in an aerial attack on the South Vietnamese leadership; 26 February 1962 Two A-1 from the VNAF 1st FS attacked President Diems Palace in Saigon. The reason was a personal vendetta with one of the Presidents brothers. One A-1 was shot down by ground fire and the pilot captured, the other A-1 escaped to Cambodia and crash landed near Phnom Penh. Lt Pham Phu Quoc was shot down, Lt Nguyen Van Cu fled to Cambodia, possibly in A-1H 137587. forum.12oclockhigh.net/showthread.php?t=12393 Picture in text of two former VNAF A-1H in Cambodia: www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_410.shtml During the early 1960s Cambodia served as a safe heaven for a number of South Vietnamese defectors. The A-1H in the foreground was a former mount of the 518th Sqn Vietnam Air Force, and flown to Phnom Penh in 1964 by a pilot protesting against the persecution of Buddhists by the regime in Saigon. The Skyraider was put into Cambodian service alongside French-delivered A-1Ds. Interestingly, the A-1 in the rear of this photo is another ex-South Vietnamese example, and the one that crashed while landing in Pnom Penh on 26 February 1962, [134495] after a coup-attempt against President Diem. More information on the incident with pictures of actual aircraft in the raid vnafmamn.com/PhamPhuQuoc_AirRaid.html A-1H 137587 is not seen, however A-1H 137584 is pictured. There is however reference here to AD-6/A-1H 137587: www.joebaugher.com/navy_serials/thirdseries16.html (courtesy Professor Joe Baugher, Chicago, Illinois) That AD-6/A-1H 137587 “to Cambodian AF by 1972” So it may have been flown there ? The ultimate fate of this aircraft is as yet unknown.
